stories.text: I bang on about Software Literacy as a concept a lot - that software is a new form of literacy just like writing itself is a technology, and I was wondering how to measure this.  So some estimates are 40M programmers globally - which is 1/200 people globally (pretty low rate).  But what about those nice middle class (western) companies most of us work in.  What's your estimate of people who have for example, committed code to the company repo(s) in the past month?
stories.title: Ask HN: Code commit % rate at your company?

stories.text:
When I search for phones with 3GB+ RAM and <=140mm height, there's only iPhone SE, iPhone 12 mini, and iPhone 13 mini.

The fact that Apple released 3 phones in 3 years with this form factor shows me that it is a profitable market segment and that there is demand.

Why is there no Android equivalent?

https://m.gsmarena.com/results.php3?nYearMin=2019&nHeightMax=140&nRamMin=3000
stories.title: Ask HN: Why is there no small Android phone?

stories.text:
Big Search is a browser extension (Firefox+Chrome) to use / switch any one or multiple search engines. Source code on Github <https://github.com/garywill/BigSearch> .

Besides basic features, it is with some special technical features also.

For example, it works with those websites that don't provide GET/POST interface to public (so-called Ajax-only websites). Visitor need to open their page and input, then they show search results on page via Ajax. Big Search can turn such Ajax-only websites into search engines and add them to browser.

Chrome Extension API doc ( https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/reference/ ) is one of such Ajax-only websites. That's a simple one. There're more such websites with more complicated js involved to do search, which still need us to figure out.

Big Search repo on Github : https://github.com/garywill/BigSearch
stories.title: Multi-search addon turning no-query-interface websites into search engines
